channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Civil Society Activists Detained as Anniversary Looms
item.description: The Beijing police detained as many as nine activists planning a seminar on obstacles facing gay groups, one of the organizers said, a sign of the authorities’ anxiety as the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown approaches.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Yu Fangqiang, from his Sina Weibo homepage.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Police to Help With Tourist Influx in Paris
item.description: The move comes as Chinese travelers in France have experienced a rising number of robberies and assaults, according to a French news agency.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Agnes Dherbeys for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese tourists outside the Galeries Lafayette department store in Paris.

item.title: Lens Blog: Italy’s Independence in Postwar Photography
item.description: The years after World War II were chaotic for Italy, but they also brought great creative freedom to photographers who, like their counterparts in cinema, embraced realism.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By RENA SILVERMAN

item.title: Vietnamese Navy Confronts Chinese Ships in Oil Rig Dispute
item.description: The confrontation highlighted the region’s hair-trigger tensions as East Asian nations try to contain China’s more aggressive posture in pursuing maritime claims.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY and DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: India Ink: Indian-Born Tibetans Allowed to Vote, but Few Take Up Offer
item.description: Indian-born Tibetans are reluctant to register as voters because they fear it is a step toward integrating with a country they hope to leave one day for their true home.
item.dc:creator: By ANURADHA SHARMA
item.media:description: Tenzin Tsundue, a poet-activist, in front of his house in Dharamsala, in the northern Indian state of Himachal Pradesh, on March 17.

item.title: Court Orders Thai Leader Removed From Office
item.description: The ruling that Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra abused her power could intensify the political turmoil in Thailand.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Highlights of The Times’s Alibaba Coverage
item.description: An overview of The Times’s coverage of the multifaceted impact of Alibaba’s announcement Tuesday that it is going public.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: South Africans Vote as Zuma Seeks Second Term as President
item.description: Polls suggest President Jacob G. Zuma’s party, the African National Congress, will steamroll to victory, but with less support than in the past.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: A voter cast his ballot in Qunu, South Africa, on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: May 7
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: A soldier boarding a bus to accompany election officials to their polling stations on the eve of the eighth phase of parliamentary elections in Leh in the state of Jammu and Kashmir on Tuesday.

item.title: Masala Dosa to Die For
item.description: How the founder of one of the world’s largest vegetarian restaurant chains got away with murder.
item.dc:creator: By ROLLO ROMIG
item.media:credit: Mahesh Shantaram for The New York Times
item.media:description: P. Rajagopal, center, at home surrounded by his staff.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Another Violent Attack at Railway Station in China
item.description: The assault in Guangzhou, the third in China since March, is likely to further unnerve a nation struggling to cope with increasingly frequent attacks on civilians in high-profile public areas.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: A man whom local media called a suspect in a knife attack was detained Tuesday in Guangzhou.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S. Air Force Aids Rescue of Chinese Fishermen in Pacific
item.description: Members of an Air Force rescue group parachuted into the Pacific Ocean off the Mexican coast to come to the aid of Chinese fishermen who had been forced to abandon their ship after it caught fire.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Staff Sgt. Adam Grant/United States Air Force, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An Air Force rescue team in a small craft approaching a Venezuelan fishing boat on Saturday after parachuting into the Pacific Ocean to help two injured Chinese on board.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rights Lawyer Detained Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
item.description: Pu Zhiqiang has been formally detained on suspicion of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble” after meeting with other rights activists and scholars to discuss the 1989 crackdown, his friends and human rights groups say.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Military Claims Sweep of 2 Qaeda Strongholds in South
item.description: Yemeni troops seized two strongholds of Al Qaeda in the south after an offensive in which dozens of militant suspects and government troops were killed.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Province Bars Entry to Those Not Vaccinated for Polio
item.description: One Pakistani province said Tuesday that citizens from anywhere else in the country would not be able to enter it without proof that they had been vaccinated.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: 62 Accused of Ties to Yemeni and Syrian Terrorists
item.description: Security authorities have arrested 62 militants accused of having ties to terrorists in Yemen and Syria and who are suspected of planning attacks on government installations.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Mayor Ford Flew to U.S.
item.description: Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto decided not to try to officially enter the United States shortly after flying there on Thursday, hours after saying he would take a leave of absence to seek treatment.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Uruguay: Government Sets Rules for Legal Sales of Marijuana
item.description: President José Mujica and his cabinet signed long-awaited rules for Uruguay’s legal marijuana marketplace on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Vietnam: Warning Issued to China Over Oil Rig in Disputed Waters
item.description: Vietnam warned China on Tuesday that it would take all necessary measures to defend its interests in the South China Sea if China did not remove a large oil rig from waters claimed by both countries.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Witness in Terrorism Case Recalls Being Taken Hostage in Yemen
item.description: Testifying in Manhattan at the trial of Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, who is accused of aiding in the abduction of 16 tourists in Yemen, a woman described her ordeal.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, an Egyptian-born cleric, in 2004.

item.title: Russia Quietly Tightens Reins on Web With ‘Bloggers Law’
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin has signed a new law requiring popular online voices to register with the government.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday. A new law he signed requires popular online voices to register with the government.

item.title: Local Policies Help an Indian Candidate Trying to Go National
item.description: Narendra Modi, the front-runner for prime minister, has a reputation in the state of Gujarat for brushing aside political and regulatory obstacles that stall construction in other parts of India.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: New Kidnapping Reported in Nigeria as U.S. Offers Help
item.description: The abduction of at least eight more girls came as the Obama administration announced that it had offered to help find and prosecute those responsible for the mass abduction last month, claimed by the Boko Haram extremist group.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Demonstrators called for the government to rescue the kidnapped girls outside defense headquarters in Abuja, Nigeria, on Tuesday.

item.title: Brash Ukrainian Mogul Prepares to Fight U.S. Bribery Charges
item.description: Dmitry V. Firtash, who was arrested on bribery charges in March, insists he is not the pro-Russian caricature of corruption that the Americans are making him out to be.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Heinz S. Tesarek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dmitry V. Firtash, who was arrested in March, is not shy about his political influence.

item.title: Boston College Says It Will Return Interviews About Northern Ireland
item.description: Fearing their accounts will be exposed, interviewees for an oral history project on the Troubles in Northern Ireland have sought the return of tapes and transcripts.
item.dc:creator: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
